question: If <katex>$r_p$</katex>, <katex>$v_p$</katex>, <katex>$L_p$</katex> and <katex>$r_a$</katex>, <katex>$v_a$</katex>, <katex>$L_a$</katex> are radii, velocities and angular momenta of a planet at perihelion and aphelion of its elliptical orbit around the Sun respectively, then
explanation: Angular momentum is conserved in planetary motion, so <katex>$L_p = L_a$</katex>.
Perihelion is the closest point to the sun, so <katex>$r_p < r_a$</katex>.
By conservation of angular momentum <katex>$m v_p r_p = m v_a r_a$</katex>. Since <katex>$r_p < r_a$</katex>, it implies <katex>$v_p > v_a$</katex>.
